Description: This video presents a different set of characteristics of life. How does this set differ from the one given by the concept? How are they similar? You can stop at 6:08. (The video mentions some topics covered in later concepts.)
A concise video that sheds light on an often discussed topic, evolution, by examining some of the misconceptions about evolution.
A simple, yet insightful video explaining what carbohydrates look like, their chemical structures, their reaction in water, and their roles in organisms.
A video on lipids, why they're structured the way they are, and their uses in the human body. This video goes into some details about chemical bonds.
A brief video that explains the distinction between eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells.
This video explains the plasma membrane, the ways in which solids, liquids, and gases move in and out of cells, and passive transport.
This video takes a tour of a plant's cell and points out how plant cells differ from animal cells. The video also looks at unique characteristics that only some plants have.

This Khan Academy video goes over diffusion and osmosis (covered in another concept). The detail goes into more detail about why molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration.
This video also covers passive transport, but the majority of the video looks at facilitated and active transport.
A brief introductory video to chromosomes.
This detailed video shows an animation that takes you through the steps of transcription.
This video shows an animation that takes you through the steps from translating a RNA to protein.
This video describes what the atmosphere of the earth was like long ago and how life first started.
This video looks at the flow of energy starting from the sun. The video covers food chain, food web, and trophic level.
This video defines biodiversity and looks at types of biodiversity.
This video is an overview of the cause of global warming and its possible effects on the world.
A very informative video about annelids, the various types, their respective habitats, and their shared characteristics.
A video giving an overview of bird evolution.
This video is a medical animation of the breathing process.

Resource Name: How Simple Ideas Lead to Scientific Discoveries (7:32)
Authors: Adam Savage; Kari Mulholland; Jeremiah Dickey; Franz Palomares; Celeste Lai
Description: This video talks about two instances in which huge realizations are made from simple questions.
Titles: How Simple Ideas Lead to Scientific Discoveries

Description: Watch a clip from the Simpsons that parodies how life evolved. Keep in mind that this is just a fun video and is not an accurate portrayal of evolution. Can you recognize some of the inaccuracies?

Resource Name: ET is (Probably) Out There - Get Ready (18:37)
Description: In this intriguing video, researcher Seth Shostak explains why the discovery of intelligent life outside of our planet very likely. He also forecasts how the discovery of civilizations far more advanced than ours might affect us here on Earth.
Titles: ET is (Probably) Out There - Get Ready

Description: A short video that explains succinctly what proteins are and why it is important to understand what amino acids are. This video assumes knowledge about functional groups and some basic chemistry knowledge.

Resource Name: How to Speed Up Chemical Reactions (and Get a Date) (4:56)
Description: This is a fun video that describes how to speed up chemical reactions.
Titles: How to Speed Up Chemical Reactions (and Get a Date)

Resource Name: Flu Attack! How A Virus Invades Your Body (3:39)
Description: This is a video describing how a viral infection works. You can see that the virus does not reproduce on its own but instead "tricks" the host cell into making millions of copies of the virus.
Titles: Flu Attack! How A Virus Invades your Body

Description: This video contains a nice song explaining the role of nucleus in a cell.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.226.L.1, SCI.BIO.227.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.227.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.324.L.1, SCI.BIO.325.L.1, SCI.BIO.327.L.1, SCI.BIO.232.L.1
Description: This video takes you on a virtual tour through a cell and ties together several concepts. The video not only examines cell organelles (including chloroplasts), but also looks at transcription, translation, and ATP synthase.
A brief but clear video presentation of the differences between exocytosis and endocytosis, for those who find visuals easier to understand.
This video shows how anaerobic glycolysis happens in the human body while humans are running and playing sports.
This video goes over fermentation and its applications in food, and also shows how to make homemade ginger ale using fermentation.
This video briefly describes sex determination in different organisms.

This video illustrates a problem that can occur during gametogenesis. Down's syndrome arises when two sister chromatids fail to separate during the final stages of meiosis. Start at 1:10 if you just want to see the nondisjunction.
This is an interesting video about developments in mapping the human genome and figuring out the implications that such developments have on society in the future.

Description: This is a video with an overview of  4 different sections of biotechnology, genetics, biofuel, health, and agriculture.

Resource Name: The Life-Code that will Reshape the Future (22:24)
Description: This video looks at some of the developments in genomics, a field that studies the genomes of living things.

Description: What are some of the ethical implications of genetic modification, neuroscience, and other biotechnological breakthroughs? In this video a chief bioethicist at NASA explores some of these implications.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010X/Blank/PaulWolpe_2010X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/PaulWolpe-2010X.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1103&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=paul_root_wolpe_it_s_time_to_question_bio_engineering;year=2010;theme=technology_history_and_destiny;theme=tales_of_invention;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=TEDxPeachtree;tag=biology;tag=biomechanics;tag=future;tag=genetics;tag=philosophy;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010X/Blank/PaulWolpe_2010X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/PaulWolpe-2010X.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1103&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=paul_root_wolpe_it_s_time_to_question_bio_engineering;year=2010;theme=technology_history_and_destiny;theme=tales_of_invention;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=TEDxPeachtree;tag=biology;tag=biomechanics;tag=future;tag=genetics;tag=philosophy;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: This video shows a graphical representation of the transcription of DNA to proteins. This is a very cool video, but it is quite long, so feel free to skip around a little. Note: This is a representation and our cells do not contain mechanized organelles.
This video contains a song about DNA to the tune of Bruno Mar's "Grenade." A fun way to review the genetic code and base pairing.
This is a 2-hour documentary on the Human Genome Project, a project to decode and record our DNA. The Human Genome Project ended in 2003 with the completion of the decoding of the human genome.
Embed Code: Watch Cracking the Code of Life on PBS. See more from NOVA.

Description: The video at this link talks about how photosynthetic organisms transformed the Earth's atmosphere and life on Earth.

Resource Name: How did the Evolution of Complex Life on Earth Begin? - The Gene Code, Episode 1 (4:17)
Description: This video gives a general overview about the puzzle of the evolution of complex cells and how we think the evolution happened.  It also explains the significance of this moment.
Titles: How did the Evolution of Complex Life on Earth Begin? - The Gene Code, Episode 1

Resource Name: Will Our Kids Be a Different Species? (16:49)
Description: This fascinating video centers around the critical question: are humans evolving into a new species, and if so, at what rate? Juan Enriquez talks through the history of human evolution, genetic engineering, and mental "disorders."
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012S/Blank/JuanEnriquez_2012S-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/JuanEnriquez_2012S-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1467&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=juan_enriquez_will_our_kids_be_a_different_species;year=2012;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=TEDxSummit;tag=brain;tag=culture;tag=evolution;tag=genetics;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012S/Blank/JuanEnriquez_2012S-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/JuanEnriquez_2012S-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1467&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=juan_enriquez_will_our_kids_be_a_different_species;year=2012;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=TEDxSummit;tag=brain;tag=culture;tag=evolution;tag=genetics;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: Will Our Kids Be a Different Species?

Description: This video teaches some quick tips to help you remember the 5 causes of evolution of species.

Authors: Jason Munshi-South; Kari Mulholland; Biljana Labovic; Franz Palomares; Celeste Lai
Description: A video that examines the dynamics of evolution in some animals in urban environments.
This video contains a song about the water cycle to the tune of Pitbull's "Give Me Everything Tonight." A fun way to review the water cycle.

Resource Name: Bill Nye the Science Guy: Water Cycle (2:58)
Description: This clip from Bill Nye the Science Guy looks at condensation and how to make a cloud in a glass jug.
Titles: Bill Nye the Science Guy: Water Cycle

Description: This video gives a brief explanation on how the nitrogen cycle works.

Authors: David Gallo; Kari Mulholland; Biljana Labovic; Franz Palomares; Celeste Lai
Description: In this video, Dave Gallo takes the audience through an amazing exploration of the deep ocean. Humans have only explored about 5% of the deep ocean and already we have found incredible life that changes our view of the world.

Resource Name: How Life Begins in the Deep Ocean (6:02)
Authors: Tierney Thys; Christian Sardet; Noe Sardet; Sharif Mirshak
Description: A video on how various deep sea inhabitants produce and care for their young.
Titles: How Life Begins in the Deep Ocean

Description: A video containing a song about symbiosis sung to the tune of Coldplay's "Paradise." A good way to review the concept.

Resource Name: How did Plant Life Begin in Hawaii? (5:14)
Authors: WGBH Educational Foundation; Peace River Films, Incorporated.
Description: The video at this link talks about how plant life began in Hawaii, in spite of its isolation. It gives a good demonstration of ecological succession.
Titles: How did Plant Life Begin in Hawaii?

Description: This video shows human population growth from 0 AD to 2030 (last twenty years are projected).

Resource Name: Hans Rosling Shows the Best Stats You've Ever Seen (19:54)
Description: In this video, Hans Rosling uses a variety of graphs and projections to illustrate the correlation between countries' life expectancy, fertility rate, population growth, and standards of living.
Titles: Hans Rosling Shows the Best Stats You've Ever Seen

Description: Video describing the recent human population boom and what we will have to change in the future.
This video looks at biodiversity in the tropical rainforests.

Resource Name: Sylvia Earle’s TED Prize Wish to Protect our Oceans (18:12)
Description: In this video, Sylvia Earle talks about the importance of protecting our oceans and the extend to which we've already depleted the oceans.
Titles: Sylvia Earle’s TED Prize Wish to Protect our Oceans

Description: This video details the gram stain process used to categorize bacteria.
This video explores some of the different habitats that prokaryotes live in.
This video shows a real-world example of gene transfer and how it helps plants.
In this video, Eisen introduces us to the thousands of microbes living in and on our bodies and tells us a little bit about our studies of microbes.

Resource Name: Steven Johnson Tours the Ghost Map (10:07)
Description: In this video, Johnson recounts the cholera outbreak in 1854 London and its profound impacts on scientific study and modern society.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2006S/Blank/StevenJohnson_2006S-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/StevenJohnson-2006S.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=61&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=steven_johnson_tours_the_ghost_map;year=2006;theme=the_power_of_cities;theme=technology_history_and_destiny;theme=unconventional_explanations;theme=architectural_inspiration;event=TEDSalon+2006;tag=cities;tag=culture;tag=design;tag=epidemiology;tag=health;tag=history;tag=map;tag=science;tag=urban+planning;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2006S/Blank/StevenJohnson_2006S-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/StevenJohnson-2006S.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=61&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=steven_johnson_tours_the_ghost_map;year=2006;theme=the_power_of_cities;theme=technology_history_and_destiny;theme=unconventional_explanations;theme=architectural_inspiration;event=TEDSalon+2006;tag=cities;tag=culture;tag=design;tag=epidemiology;tag=health;tag=history;tag=map;tag=science;tag=urban+planning;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: Steven Johnson Tours the Ghost Map

Description: This video describes the world's pandemics and how they spread.

Resource Name: Zoonotic Diseases - Danger in our Backyards (1:45)
Description: This video talks about zoonosis and how it is a very prevalent danger. It also gives advice on how to avoid it.
Titles: Zoonotic Diseases - Danger in our Backyards

Resource Name: HIV Research: Seeking Solutions in Africa (3:33)
Description: This video shows how people are trying to find a solution to such a big problem. It presents statistics as to why this disease is such a big pandemic. It also talks about a touching real-life story of a young girl.
Titles: HIV Research: Seeking Solutions in Africa

Description: This video talks about a specific example about a virus becoming a pandemic and how the WHO responded on a global scale.
This video takes you through the human body and shows exactly where gene therapy takes place.
This is a fascinating video about the life and survival of plankton. While it focuses mainly on regular plankton, it briefly mentions phytoplankton and other algae, which all live in a similar way.
A video describing how penicillin was discovered and it's uses.

Resource Name: Fungi Plant Growth - The Private Life of Plants (1:34)
Description: An amazing video that takes a look at how fungi grows, gives off spores, and decays.
Titles: Fungi Plant Growth - The Private Life of Plants

Resource Name: Venus Fly Trap - The Private Life of Plants (3:29)
Description: This is a video on the Venus fly trap and a pitcher plant.  Both are carnivorous plants that digest small animals, mainly insects.
Titles: Venus Fly Trap - The Private Life of Plants

Description: In this video, Louie Schwartzberg shows beautiful footage of flower pollination that is sure to fill you with wonder and an appreciation of the important role plants play in life on Earth. To skip directly to the footage, start at 3:15.

Description: This video talks about the future of plants in the world and how we can preserve and protect species to improve the future of the earth.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2009U/Blank/JonathanDrori_2009U-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/JonathanDrori-2009U.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=556&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=jonathan_drori_why_we_re_storing_billions_of_seeds;year=2009;theme=a_greener_future;theme=ted_in_3_minutes;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=TED2009;tag=biodiversity;tag=biology;tag=biosphere;tag=environment;tag=future;tag=life;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2009U/Blank/JonathanDrori_2009U-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/JonathanDrori-2009U.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=556&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=jonathan_drori_why_we_re_storing_billions_of_seeds;year=2009;theme=a_greener_future;theme=ted_in_3_minutes;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=bold_predictions_stern_warnings;event=TED2009;tag=biodiversity;tag=biology;tag=biosphere;tag=environment;tag=future;tag=life;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: In this video, Driori shares some of the amazing tricks flowers use to encourage pollen distribution.
In this video witness the amazing growth of bamboo.
A video containing a song about the life cycles of the plant as well as plant structure to the tune of LMFAO's "Party Rock." A fun way to review plant life cycles.
In this video, Karen Bass shares footage of incredible animals (and new species!). You can see how these animals behave in their natural environment.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012/Blank/KarenBass_2012-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/KarenBass_2012-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1442&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=karen_bass_unseen_footage_untamed_nature;year=2012;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TED2012;tag=animals;tag=film;tag=nature;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012/Blank/KarenBass_2012-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/KarenBass_2012-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1442&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=karen_bass_unseen_footage_untamed_nature;year=2012;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TED2012;tag=animals;tag=film;tag=nature;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: This video shows how apes are intelligent and can do some key things that humans can do.
This is an interesting video that first talks briefly about deep sea creatures but then switches its focus to mollusks such as octopi and squid.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2007/Blank/DavidGallo_2007-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/DavidGallo-2007.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=206&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=david_gallo_shows_underwater_astonishments;year=2007;theme=ocean_stories;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=inspired_by_nature;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TED2007;tag=animals;tag=evolution;tag=exploration;tag=fish;tag=oceans;tag=science;tag=short+talk;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2007/Blank/DavidGallo_2007-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/DavidGallo-2007.embed_thumbnail.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=206&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=david_gallo_shows_underwater_astonishments;year=2007;theme=ocean_stories;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=inspired_by_nature;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TED2007;tag=animals;tag=evolution;tag=exploration;tag=fish;tag=oceans;tag=science;tag=short+talk;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: While a little whimsical, this fun video has a fish, frog, tortoise, bird, and lion "talk" about their characteristics. Can you recognize what the distinguishing traits are for these classes of vertebrates?
This is an awesome video introduction to reptiles, how they survive, their mating habits, and generally the way they adapted to a cold-blooded system.

In this video, Frans de Waal addresses the frequently debated question: do animals exhibit moral behavior like humans do? Learn about several fascinating experiments that dive into the heart of the question.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2011X/Blank/FransDeWaal_2011X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/FransDeWaal_2011X-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1417&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=frans_de_waal_do_animals_have_morals;year=2011;theme=how_the_mind_works;event=TEDxPeachtree;tag=animals;tag=community;tag=morality;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2011X/Blank/FransDeWaal_2011X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/FransDeWaal_2011X-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1417&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=frans_de_waal_do_animals_have_morals;year=2011;theme=how_the_mind_works;event=TEDxPeachtree;tag=animals;tag=community;tag=morality;tag=science;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: The video at this link demonstrates a mammal's locomotion in action. Watch a cheetah utilizing its fast limbed body to take down a nearby gazelle. You can explore additional resources on the right (such as the anatomy of a cheetah).

Authors: Greg Gage; Kari Mulholland; Biljana Labovic; Franz Palomares
Description: In this video, Greg Gage uses an amputated leg of a cockroach to illustrate the electric impulses the leg receives from the brain and the leg's response.

In this video, Neil Harbisson, born without color vision, wears an incredible piece of technology, the eyeborg, which translates colors into a symphony of sounds that Neil can associate with more colors than normal human vision can see.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012G/Blank/NeilHarbisson_2012G-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/NeilHarbisson_2012G-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1512&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=neil_harbisson_i_listen_to_color;year=2012;theme=presentation_innovation;theme=what_s_next_in_tech;theme=art_unusual;event=TEDGlobal+2012;tag=art;tag=cyborg;tag=design;tag=entertainment;tag=innovation;tag=music;tag=prosthetics;tag=sound;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012G/Blank/NeilHarbisson_2012G-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/NeilHarbisson_2012G-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1512&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=neil_harbisson_i_listen_to_color;year=2012;theme=presentation_innovation;theme=what_s_next_in_tech;theme=art_unusual;event=TEDGlobal+2012;tag=art;tag=cyborg;tag=design;tag=entertainment;tag=innovation;tag=music;tag=prosthetics;tag=sound;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Resource Name: Penn Engineers Replicate the Sense of Touch (4:09)
Description: In this video you learn about Haptics. Haptics is a field of engineering that is focused on replicating the sense of touch. Simulating the feeling of a surface could make for more immersive entertainment, more edifying educational tools, or more realistic training devices.
Titles: Penn Engineers Replicate the Sense of Touch

Authors: George Zaiden; Aaron Augenblick; Hal Lee; Lisa Thomas; Iona Nistor
Description: This video describing the effect of pain relievers on your body. Briefly illustrates how ibuprofen and aspirin work.

Resource Name: Jill Bolte Taylor's Stroke of Insight (18:42)
Description: An interesting video where Neurologist Jill Bolte Taylor undergoes an incredible discovery when she wakes one morning to find herself having a stroke.
Titles: Jill Bolte Taylor's Stroke of Insight

Resource Name: A New Way to Diagnose Autism (22:08)
Description: In this video, Ami Klin talks about autism and new ways technology can be used to attenuate the symptoms.
Titles: A New Way to Diagnose Autism

Resource Name: How I Repaired My Own Heart (13:14)
Description: An amazing video! A boiler engineer opts out of the usual aorta surgery, instead creating his own device and surgery to heal his heart.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2011X/Blank/TalGolesworthy_2011X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/TalGolesworthy_2011X-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1419&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=tal_golesworthy_how_i_repaired_my_own_heart;year=2011;theme=medicine_without_borders;theme=tales_of_invention;event=TEDxKrakow;tag=engineering;tag=health;tag=innovation;tag=medicine;tag=science;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2011X/Blank/TalGolesworthy_2011X-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/TalGolesworthy_2011X-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1419&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=tal_golesworthy_how_i_repaired_my_own_heart;year=2011;theme=medicine_without_borders;theme=tales_of_invention;event=TEDxKrakow;tag=engineering;tag=health;tag=innovation;tag=medicine;tag=science;tag=technology;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: How I Repaired My Own Heart

Description: In this video, Mike Evans talks about how important exercise is and its affects on lowering the chance of certain issues (obesity, high blood pressure, etc.).

While this video talks specifically of an immune response to a virus, the principles it touches upon relate to inflammatory responses. The video mentions white blood cells (leukocytes), their role in fighting of viruses, and how they do so.

Resource Name: What We Didn't Know about Penis Anatomy (11:20)
Description: Although it may seem like we know everything about anatomy, there are still basic facts that we’re still learning. This video looks at how the mammalian erection work.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012P/Blank/DianeKelly_2012P-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/DianeKelly_2012P-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1468&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=diane_kelly_what_we_didn_t_know_about_penis_anatomy;year=2012;theme=women_reshaping_the_world;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TEDMED+2012;tag=biology;tag=science;tag=sex;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2012P/Blank/DianeKelly_2012P-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/DianeKelly_2012P-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1468&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=diane_kelly_what_we_didn_t_know_about_penis_anatomy;year=2012;theme=women_reshaping_the_world;theme=evolution_s_genius;theme=animals_that_amaze;event=TEDMED+2012;tag=biology;tag=science;tag=sex;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>
Titles: What We Didn't Know about Penis Anatomy

Description: In this video, Tsiaras presents a simulation showing the development of a baby from oocyte to birthing. WARNING: This video contains some graphic pictures of childbirth.
Embed Code: <object width="526" height="374"><param name="movie" value="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="always"/><param name="wmode" value="transparent"></param><param name="bgColor" value="#ffffff"></param><param name="flashvars" value="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010P/Blank/AlexanderTsiaras_2010P-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/AlexanderTsiaras_2010P-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1270&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=alexander_tsiaras_conception_to_birth_visualized;year=2010;theme=medicine_without_borders;theme=art_unusual;theme=tales_of_invention;event=INK+Conference;tag=design;tag=medical+research;tag=science;tag=visualizations;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;" /><embed src="http://video.ted.com/assets/player/swf/EmbedPlayer.swf" pluginspace="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="transparent" bgColor="#ffffff" width="526" height="374" allowFullScreen="true" allowScriptAccess="always" flashvars="vu=http://video.ted.com/talk/stream/2010P/Blank/AlexanderTsiaras_2010P-320k.mp4&su=http://images.ted.com/images/ted/tedindex/embed-posters/AlexanderTsiaras_2010P-embed.jpg&vw=512&vh=288&ap=0&ti=1270&lang=en&introDuration=15330&adDuration=4000&postAdDuration=830&adKeys=talk=alexander_tsiaras_conception_to_birth_visualized;year=2010;theme=medicine_without_borders;theme=art_unusual;theme=tales_of_invention;event=INK+Conference;tag=design;tag=medical+research;tag=science;tag=visualizations;&preAdTag=tconf.ted/embed;tile=1;sz=512x288;"></embed></object>

Description: Curious about how real people use the scientific method in real life? At this link, select the "What is the Scientific Method?" lesson to learn how each step of the scientific method is critical to better understanding the world around us.
This website has a video about scientific theory, a song video about the scientific method, and a short quiz.
At this link, explore the difference between living and nonliving with this interactive website.
An interactive that zooms into the human body and shows individual DNA and RNA fibers.
At this link, click on "Enzymes: The Basics" to review the characteristics and properties of enzymes. You can click on the other topics to explore and learn more about enzymes.
An interactive activity that examines how enzymes affect and interact with their substrate.

Resource Name: Strong Acid and Weak Acid Ionization
Description: This website has two short animations that examine the differences between strong and weak acids in more detail.
At this link, experience an in-depth, interactive journey into a cell.

Resource Name: Membrane Structure: The Fluid Mosaic Model
Authors: Sinauer Associates, Inc.; W. H. Freeman Co; Sumanas Inc.
Description: This animation shows a model of a cell membrane and all of its moving parts.
This link contains an overview of diffusion and osmosis, presented in a part video/part interactive format.
This link has videos, questions and explanations about osmosis.

Resource Name: Passive Transport - Filtration and Facilitated Diffusion
Description: At this link, you can see animations and explanations on facilitated diffusion.
Trying to study the structure of a chloroplast? Play this game to test yourself. Can you label everything quickly and correctly?
This website reviews the processes in photosynthesis.
A game that examines the way autotrophs produce food for the entire food web through photosynthesis.
This animation shows a model of a cell membrane and all of its moving parts.
An animation of the cellular respiration process.
At this link, explore an interactive walkthrough that allows you to test your knowledge on the cell cycle.
At this website, Use Punnett squares to ensure the bunny offspring have the ideal characteristics for their environment.
If you want to learn the molecular structure of the amino acids and then test yourself, try this game. You can hit "Quit" first to study the molecular structures.
This is an interesting interactive that shows what happened immediately following the Big Bang. Make sure you click on all of the pictures along the top!
This webiste contains a timeline that follows evolutionary landmarks from the Precambrian Period to the Cenozoic Era. Click on the dots on the screen to learn more about each big event.
This Google Earth globe shows the average energy use in major countries.
This interactive resource has an overview of 6 different protists.
This resource explores the life cycle of dinoflagellate.

Resource Name: The Phases of the Plant Life Cycle
Description: This informational text has 5 pages of details and diagrams about each stage in the plant cycle. It also has a game to test your knowledge and to grow your own virtual plant.
An interactive diagram that shows the network inside vascular plants and how food and water travel through this network.
This interactive activity has animations of photosynthesis along with text descriptions.
This interactive diagram of the life cycle of a fern has a description and videos or images of each stage in the life cycle.
This activity has an introduction and animated video on the gymnosperm life cycle. There is also a quiz to test your knowledge.

Authors: Sinauer Associates; W. H. Freeman & Co.; Sumanas, Inc.
Description: This activity has an introduction and animated video on the angiosperm life cycle. There is also a quiz to test your knowledge.
This website is a fun way to organize each characteristics into their respective animal groups.

An interactive that allows you to choose the average bpm of a heart. It shows you a step by step process of what a heart looks like beating and how it functions (day and night), providing helpful facts along the way.
At this link, explore an interactive diagram of the kidney.
This website examines the global carbon budget and the impacts humans have on the natural carbon cycle.
This website simulates the projected population growth based on several factors including birth rates, death rates, and the country.
